articles.headline: Obama Willing to Use Executive Orders on Guns
articles.snippet: President Obama this week is expected to embrace a plan to reduce gun violence that will also lay out separate actions he could take himself, without approval from Congress.
articles.abstract: President Obama this week is expected to embrace a plan to reduce gun violence that will also lay out separate actions he could take himself, without approval from Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama this week will embrace a comprehensive plan to reduce gun violence that will call for major legislation to expand background checks for gun purchases and lay out 19 separate actions the president could take by invoking the power of his office, lawmakers who were briefed on the plan said Monday.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: In Unlikely Comeback, Chrysler Is Outgaining Bigger Detroit Rivals
articles.snippet: The carmaker’s chief executive said he expected the upward sales trend to continue, bolstering both Chrysler and its parent, Fiat.
articles.abstract: The carmaker’s chief executive said he expected the upward sales trend to continue, bolstering both Chrysler and its parent, Fiat.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Just a few years ago, as it plunged into bankruptcy, Chrysler was a wreck of a company. But strong sales and hot new products have made the automaker the envy of Detroit.

articles.headline: Worry Over Sales Spurs Talk of Cheaper iPhones
articles.snippet: Analysts say Apple must decide whether to keep catering to the high end of the market or offer something cheaper.
articles.abstract: Analysts say Apple must decide whether to keep catering to the high end of the market or offer something cheaper.
articles.lead_paragraph: By now, most of the world knows what an iPhone is — and they know it typically doesn’t come cheap.

articles.headline: To Get Movies Into China, Hollywood Gives Censors a Preview
articles.snippet: Eager to tap China’s movie market, Hollywood studios try to win censors’ approval — taking on Chinese partners, tweaking story lines and, when filming in China, inviting bureaucrats to the set.
articles.abstract: Eager to tap China’s movie market, Hollywood studios try to win censors’ approval — taking on Chinese partners, tweaking story lines and, when filming in China, inviting bureaucrats to the set.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When “Kung Fu Panda 3” kicks its way into China’s theaters in 2016, the country’s vigilant film censors will find no nasty surprises.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Fortunes of Facebook May Hinge on Searches
articles.snippet: Improving its ability to find treasure amid junk offers Facebook a chance to topple Google from the throne as the king of search.
articles.abstract: Improving its ability to find treasure amid junk offers Facebook a chance to topple Google from the throne as the king of search.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Nearly a year after it announced its bid to go public, Facebook is confronting the ultimate burden of the information age: how to help its users find what they are looking for amid the billions of pictures, “likes” and status updates they post every day.

articles.headline: Morsi’s Slurs Against Jews Stir Concern
articles.snippet: Anti-Semitic remarks that President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt made in 2010 have raised doubts about his efforts to present himself as a force for moderation.
articles.abstract: Anti-Semitic remarks that President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt made in 2010 have raised doubts about his efforts to present himself as a force for moderation.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Nearly three years ago, a leader of the Muslim Brotherhood delivered a speech urging Egyptians to “nurse our children and our grandchildren on hatred” for Jews and Zionists. In a television interview months later, the same leader described Zionists as “these bloodsuckers who attack the Palestinians, these warmongers, the descendants of apes and pigs.”

articles.headline: The Banker Who Put His Faith in Armstrong
articles.snippet: Thomas Weisel was Lance Armstrong’s biggest financial backer and the single individual most responsible for the money machine that propelled Mr. Armstrong’s career.
articles.abstract: Thomas Weisel was Lance Armstrong’s biggest financial backer and the single individual most responsible for the money machine that propelled Mr. Armstrong’s career.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Lance Armstrong’s interview with Oprah Winfrey about his suspected use of illegal performance-enhancing drugs is broadcast on Thursday, an investment banker will most likely be watching it very carefully (and nervously): Thomas Weisel.

articles.headline: A Movie Mogul Rising
articles.snippet: Gigi Pritzker’s OddLot Entertainment picked up the pieces when Warner Brothers’ rights to “Ender’s Game” expired and began assembling its most expensive movie to date.
articles.abstract: Gigi Pritzker’s OddLot Entertainment picked up the pieces when Warner Brothers’ rights to “Ender’s Game” expired and began assembling its most expensive movie to date.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — Back when there were only a couple of “Harry Potter” pictures, and provocative youth films like “The Hunger Games” and “Twilight” were barely a twinkle in Hollywood’s eye, Warner Brothers tried — and failed — to make a movie of Orson Scott Card’s book “Ender’s Game.”

articles.headline: How Pursuit of Billionaire Hit One Dead End
articles.snippet: The investigation of SAC Capital Advisors highlights the challenges of using lower-level workers to build a case against their boss.
articles.abstract: The investigation of SAC Capital Advisors highlights the challenges of using lower-level workers to build a case against their boss.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jonathan Hollander left his high-flying job at SAC Capital Advisors in late 2008, he departed one of Wall Street’s premier hedge funds.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Ben Protess

articles.headline: California to Give Web Courses a Big Trial
articles.snippet: Udacity, a start-up that offers online college courses, will offer low-cost remedial and introductory classes to students at San Jose State University and local community colleges and high schools.
articles.abstract: Udacity, a start-up that offers online college courses, will offer low-cost remedial and introductory classes to students at San Jose State University and local community colleges and high schools.
articles.lead_paragraph: A plan to offer an array of online college classes at a California state university could, if the students are successful, open the door to teaching hundreds of thousands of California students at a lower cost via the Internet.
articles.byline: By Tamar Lewin and John Markoff

articles.headline: Internal Forces Besiege Pakistan Ahead of Voting
articles.snippet: An enigmatic preacher with thousands of followers is demanding the government’s ouster, the top court has ordered the arrest of the prime minister and violence is surging.
articles.abstract: An enigmatic preacher with thousands of followers is demanding the government’s ouster, the top court has ordered the arrest of the prime minister and violence is surging.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Barely a year after fears of a possible military coup plunged Pakistani politics into chaos, the country is in crisis again — this time besieged on multiple fronts by forces that threaten the civilian government just a few months ahead of elections.
